questions.question: A 52-year-old man was rushed to the ER with right upper quadrant pain for the last 6 hours.He had been diagnosed with gallstones 10 years ago but had not undergone any treatment.Imaging revealed gallbladder wall thickening. He underwent a cholecystectomy whichrevealed a shrunken and nodular gallbladder with a thick wall. The following was noted onmicroscopy. This condition is associated with:

options.A: Dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall

questions.explanation: This clinical scenario of chronic cholecystitis and image showing lipid-laden xanthoma cells aresuggestive of xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis. This condition results due to the rupture ofRokitansky-Aschoff sinuses.Xanthogranulomatous CholecystitisXanthoma cells972Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses are bile-filled outpouchings of the gallbladder mucosa through thegallbladder wall. They develop in reaction to chronic inflammation of the gallbladder. Eventually,they may rupture into the wall of the gallbladder. This results in the accumulation of macrophagesthat have ingested biliary phospholipids, which are called xanthoma cells.Rokitansky-Aschoff sinusLumenFlattened mucosaOutpouchingBileChronic cholecystitis may have other sequelae:••Porcelain gallbladder - dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wallHyalinizing cholecystitis - replacement of the gallbladder wall by dense fibrosis, with or withoutcalcification (leads to higher incidence of gallbladder carcinoma)• Hydrops of the gallbladder - atrophic, obstructed, dilated gallbladder containing clear fluidAcute cholecystitis includes the following variants:• Emphysematous cholecystitis - acute infection of the gallbladder by gas-forming organisms• Acalculous cholecystitis due to gallbladder stasis and ischemia

questions.question: What is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas?
questions.explanation: Pancreas divisum is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas.The pancreas develops by fusion of the larger dorsal and smaller ventral pancreatic buds. Thedorsal duct is the dominant duct during development and it drains into the minor papilla. Theventral duct drains into the major papilla. After fusion, the following ducts are formed:• Main pancreatic duct (of Wirsung) - formed by fusion of ducts of dorsal and ventral buds, drainsinto the major papilla•Accessory pancreatic duct (of Santorini) - formed by the proximal portion of the dorsal duct,drains into the minor papillaIn pancreas divisum, the ventral and dorsal ducts fail to fuse. Hence, the majority of the pancreascontinues to drain through the dominant dorsal duct that enters the duodenum at the minor973papilla while the ventral duct, along with the bile duct, drains into the major papilla. Thesepatients are more prone to pancreatitis.Pancreas divisumNormal pancreasPancreas divisumOMARROWMinor papillaCommon bileductAccessoryduct ofSantoriniMain pancreaticduct (Wirsung)Major papillaCommon bileduotDorsal duct ofSantoriniVentral duct ofWirsungThe other congenital anomalies of the pancreas are:• Annular pancreas - band-like ring of normal pancreatic tissue encircling 2nd part of duodenum,may cause obstruction•Ectopic pancreas common in stomach, duodenum, and jejunum (found in about 2% ofpostmortem exams)•Agenesis rarely seen, associated with mutations of PDX1 (homeobox gene)-

questions.question: 968A 19-year-old boy presented with severe abdominal pain for the last 24 hours with radiationto the upper back. He has had multiple similar episodes since his childhood. Family historyrevealed similar episodes in the father. Investigations revealed elevated serum levels ofamylase and lipase. Which of the following statements is not true about the given condition?

options.A: It is commonly associated with mutations in the PRSS1 gene
options.B: This boy has a 40 % lifetime risk of developing pancreatic cancer
options.C: It may be associated with mutations in the CFTR gene
options.D: Hypocalcemia is an important triggering factor this condition

questions.explanation: This clinical scenario in a young patient with positive family history of similar episodes issuggestive of hereditary pancreatitis. Acute episodes of pancreatitis can be precipitatedby hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia.The following genes are implicated in hereditary pancreatitis:•Gain-of-function mutation in trypsinogen gene (PRSS1) - most common⚫ Loss-of-function mutation in trypsin inhibitor gene (SPINK1)••⚫ Loss of CFTR - abnormal secretions that promote protein plugging, duct obstruction, leading topancreatitisHereditary pancreatitis is associated with a 40% lifetime risk of developing pancreatic cancer.

questions.question: A 65-year-old man presented with vague abdominal pain, anorexia, weight loss for the last 6months. He also reported spontaneously appearing and disappearing painful, linearlyarranged nodules at different locations on his body. On examination, thrombophlebitis andepigastric tenderness were noted. Investigations revealed elevated serum CEA and CA 19-9.Which of the following genetic mutations is most frequently associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: 974The presence of the above clinical symptoms with migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseausyndrome) and elevated serum levels of CEA and CA 19-9 in an elderly man point to a diagnosis ofpancreatic cancer. The most frequently associated mutation with this condition is K-RAS.It is attributed to the production of platelet-aggregating factors and procoagulants from the tumoror its necrotic products. Both venous and arterial thrombi can occur. Venous thrombi canembolize to the lungs.Molecular alterations involved in pancreatic carcinogenesis are:Following genes are associated with an inherited predisposition to pancreatic cancer:• BRCA2 mutation - pancreatic cancer, breast cancer, prostate cancer, and ovarian cancers• PRSS1 mutation - pancreatic carcinoma secondary to hereditary pancreatitisGeneTypeChromosomeKRAS(most common oncogene)Oncogene (activated by pointmutation)12pCDKN2A(most common tumor-suppressor gene)Tumor suppressor gene9pTP53SMAD4Tumor suppressor geneTumor suppressor gene17p18q

questions.question: A pathologist was studying a biopsy specimen from a patient with pancreatic cancer. Heobserved that it resembled ovarian stroma. What is it likely to be?
questions.explanation: Mucinous cystic neoplasms of the pancreas have dense stroma, similar to the ovarian stroma.These tumors have large cystic cavities filled with thick, tenacious mucin. They are lined bycolumnar, mucin-producing epithelium with dense stroma. This results in similarity to ovarianstroma.They usually arise in the tail of the pancreas and can be precursors to invasive carcinomas. Theyare associated with mutations in the KRAS oncogene, and the tumor-suppressor genes TP53 andRNF43.

questions.question: All of these are characteristic features of pancreatic carcinoma except:

options.A: Cigarette smoking is a risk factor
options.B: Carcinoma of body of pancreas often present with jaundice969

questions.explanation: Patients with carcinoma of the head of the pancreas develop jaundice due to obstruction of thebiliary tract.Cigarette smoking doubles the risk of pancreatic cancer and is the leading preventable cause. Theclinical features depend on the location of the tumor.• Head - painless, palpable gallbladder with mild jaundice is suggestive of malignancy (accordingto Courvoisier's law)975•Body and tail - may remain asymptomatic until later stages as they do not impinge on the biliarytract and do not cause jaundiceOther common pathological features of this condition are:• Desmoplastic reaction - growth of fibrous or connective tissue•Perineural invasion, as well as lymphatic and large vessel invasion
